education.title: The Power of Compound Interest
education.content1: Compound interest is when you earn interest on both your initial deposit and the interest you've already earned. This creates exponential growth over time.
education.content2: The more frequently interest compounds, the more you earn. Daily compounding earns slightly more than monthly, which earns more than annually.

faq.question: What's the difference between APR and APY?
faq.answer: APR is the simple interest rate. APY includes compounding, showing what you actually earn. Always compare APY for savings accounts.

faq.question: How often should I contribute?
faq.answer: More frequent contributions maximize compound growth. Monthly is ideal for most people, aligned with paychecks.

faq.question: Should I consider inflation?
faq.answer: Yes! If inflation is 3% and your savings earn 2%, you're losing purchasing power. Aim for rates that beat inflation.
